section.title: Comparatives review
section.sectiontitle: There are many expressions which show big/small differences between two things. For a small difference, use: slightly, a little bit, a tiny bit, marginally. For a big difference, use: much, far, miles, considerably.
section.text2: My last essay was longer than my first one.
section.text2a: My last essay was considerably longer than my first one.
section.sectiontitle2: As + adjective + as means the two things are equal. Not as + adjective + as means two things aren't equal (the second thing has 'more' of the quality mentioned).
section.text3a: Your house was as expensive as mine.
section.text4a: Room 58 isn't as hot as room 64 (room 58 is colder).

section.title: Comparatives review
section.sectiontitle: There are many expressions with as + adjective + as which show big/small differences. For a small difference, use: not quite as. For a big difference, use: nowhere near, nothing like.
section.text1: You're not as strong as Jim.
section.text1a: You're not quite as strong as Jim.
section.text2: She's not as rich as Samantha.
section.text2a: She's nothing like as rich as Samantha.
section.sectiontitle2: To show which of two things we prefer, use: would sooner + infinitive without to, would rather + infinitive without to, would prefer + infinitive. We sometimes use I'd prefer (to do something) rather than + infinitive without to (OR -ing form).
section.text3a: I'd sooner go on holiday than stay at home.
section.text4a: Wouldn't you rather sleep here (than at the hotel)?

section.title: Comparatives review
section.sectiontitle: Use double comparatives with the to say one thing causes another.
section.text1a: The harder you work, the better your results will be.
section.text2a: The more you complain, the angrier I get.
